user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 17.8 is: A function parameter should not be modified.
Note that the object referred to by a pointer parameter may be modified, but the pointer itself shall not be modified.
</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of OS_GenericWrite_Impl:
```c
int32 OS_GenericWrite_Impl(const OS_object_token_t *token, const void *buffer, size_t nbytes, int32 timeout)
{
    int32                           return_code;
    ssize_t                         os_result;
    uint32                          operation;
    OS_impl_file_internal_record_t *impl;

    impl = OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET(OS_impl_filehandle_table, *token);

    return_code = OS_SUCCESS;

    if (nbytes > 0)
    {
        operation = OS_STREAM_STATE_WRITABLE;

        /*
         * If filehandle is set with O_NONBLOCK, then must call select() here.
         *
         * The "selectable" field should be set false for those file handles
         * which the underlying OS does not support select() on.
         *
         * Note that a timeout will not work unless selectable is true.
         */
        if (impl->selectable)
        {
            return_code = OS_SelectSingle_Impl(token, &operation, timeout);
        }

        if (return_code == OS_SUCCESS && (operation & OS_STREAM_STATE_WRITABLE) != 0)
        {
            /* on some system libraries for which the write() argument is not
             * qualified correctly, it needs to be case to a void* here */
            os_result = write(impl->fd, GENERIC_IO_CONST_DATA_CAST buffer, nbytes);
            if (os_result < 0)
            {
                OS_DEBUG("write: %s\n", strerror(errno));
                return_code = OS_ERROR;
            }
            else
            {
                /* type conversion from ssize_t to int32 for return */
                return_code = (int32)os_result;
            }
        }
    }

    return return_code;
}
```
</target_code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation:
No function parameter is assigned to or otherwise modified in this function. Specific reasoning per parameter:
- token: Only dereferenced (*token) and passed to OS_SelectSingle_Impl(token,...). Neither operation modifies the pointer parameter itself. The assignment impl = OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET(..., *token) uses the value pointed to but does not change token.
- buffer: Only used as an argument to write() with a cast (GENERIC_IO_CONST_DATA_CAST buffer). A cast does not modify the parameter variable; it only changes the type for the call. There is no pointer arithmetic or assignment to buffer.
- nbytes: Only read (compared and passed to write()); it is not assigned or otherwise changed.
- timeout: Only passed by value to OS_SelectSingle_Impl; it is not modified.

All uses either read the parameters, dereference them, cast them for a call, or pass them to other functions. None reassign or alter the pointer variables themselves, so there are no fragments that violate MISRA C 2023 Rule 17.8 in this code.
